description: From Latin, from the participle stem of the verb dēsīderāre (“to desire”).

adjectives.description: desiderate (comparative more desiderate, superlative most desiderate)

examples: O Friend of God, know then that London is the desiderate town even of all Earth's cities.

verbs.description: desiderate (third-person singular simple present desiderates, present participle desiderating, simple past and past participle desiderated)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To miss; to feel the absence of; to long for.
examples: Between our human nature and the nature they desiderate there is a deep and fordless river, over which they can throw no bridge, and all their talk supposes that we shall be able to fly or wade across it  […]
